<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> With respect to 77 Centers, the underlying land controlled by the Company is owned in fee entirely by the Company, or, in the case of jointly-owned Centers, by the joint venture
property partnership or limited liability company. With respect to the remaining Centers, the underlying land controlled by the Company is owned by third parties and leased to the Company, the
property partnership or the limited liability company pursuant to long-term ground leases. Under the terms of a typical ground lease, the Company, the property partnership or the limited
liability company pays rent for the use of the land and is generally responsible for all costs and expenses associated with the building and improvements. In some cases, the Company, the property
partnership or the limited liability company has an option or right of first refusal to purchase the land. The termination dates of the ground leases range from 2013 to 2132.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Includes GLA attributable to Anchors (whether owned or non-owned) and Mall and Freestanding Stores as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Sales are based on reports by retailers leasing Mall and Freestanding Stores for the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 for tenants which have occupied such
stores for a
minimum of 12&nbsp;months. Sales per square foot are based on tenants 10,000 square feet and under, excluding theaters.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Portions of the land on which the Center is situated are subject to one or more ground leases.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Federated Department Stores, Inc. disclosed that it has identified duplicate locations in certain malls which will be divested during 2006. Eleven of the identified
stores are located
in 10 of the Centers.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Bon-Ton Stores,&nbsp;Inc. has acquired Herberger's and Younkers from Saks Incorporated in a transaction completed in June&nbsp;2006. Herberger's completed a
42,000
square foot expansion at Rimrock Mall in October&nbsp;2005. The Bon-Ton stores at Great Northern Mall and Shoppingtown Mall closed in January 2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Dillard's completed a 58,000 square foot expansion at Green Tree Mall in March&nbsp;2005.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At Washington Square, an agreement has been reached with Mervyn's to recapture its 100,000 square foot location. The Company plans to recycle that square footage
over the next two
years.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Nordstrom opened a new 200,000 square foot store at NorthPark Center in November&nbsp;2005.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(10)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The office portion of this mixed-use development does not have retail sales.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(11)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Target opened a new 116,000 square foot store at Valley Mall in October&nbsp;2005.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(12)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Wal-Mart opened a 206,527 square foot store at San Tan Village in January&nbsp;2005.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(13)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Home Depot opened a new 141,000 square foot store at Twenty Ninth Street in January&nbsp;2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(14)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Tenant spaces have been intentionally held off the market and remain vacant or are under construction because of major development or redevelopment plans. As a
result, the Company
believes the percentage of mall and freestanding GLA leased and the sales per square foot at these major redevelopment properties is not meaningful data.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The mortgage notes payable balances include the unamortized debt premiums (discounts). Debt premiums (discounts) represent the excess of the fair value of debt over the
principal value of debt assumed in various acquisitions. The debt premiums (discounts) are being amortized into interest expense over the term of the related debt, in a manner which approximates the
effective interest method. The annual interst rate in the above tables represent the effective interest rate, including the debt premiums (discounts).  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This annual debt service represents the payment of principal and interest. In addition, contingent interest, as defined in the loan agreement, may be due to the extent
that 35% of the amount by which the property's gross receipts (as defined in the loan agreement) exceeds a base amount specified therein. Contingent interest expense recognized by the Company was
$0.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The floating rate loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.65%. The Company has stepped interest rate cap agreements over the term of the loan that effectively prevent
LIBOR
from exceeding 7.95%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Concurrent with the acquisition of this property, the Company placed a $30.0&nbsp;million floating rate loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 0.88%. The loan matures
August&nbsp;9, 2007 with two one-year extensions through August&nbsp;9, 2009. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the total interest rate was 5.25%. This floating rate debt is covered by an
interest rate cap agreement over the loan term which effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding 7.12%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $51.0&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the total interest rate
was 6.39%. On January&nbsp;6, 2006, the Company modified the loan to reduce the interest rate to LIBOR plus 1.75% with the opportunity for further reduction upon satisfaction of certain conditions
to LIBOR plus 1.50%. The maturity date was extended to August&nbsp;1, 2008, with two extension options of eighteen and twelve months, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On June&nbsp;30, 2004, the Company placed an $85.0&nbsp;million loan maturing in 2009. The loan floated at LIBOR plus 2.0% for six months and then converted to a
fixed rate loan at 4.94%. The effective interest rate over the loan term is 4.84%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Concurrent with the acquisition of the mall, the Company placed a $108.0&nbsp;million loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15% and maturing July&nbsp;1, 2004 with
three consecutive one year options. $92.0&nbsp;million of the loan is at LIBOR plus 0.7% and $16.0&nbsp;million is at LIBOR plus 3.75%. In July&nbsp;2005, the Company extended the loan maturity
to July&nbsp;2006. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the weighted average interest rate was 5.34%.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan bore interest at LIBOR plus 1.65%. On February&nbsp;15, 2006, the existing loan was paid-off in full and replaced with a $50.0&nbsp;million
floating rate loan that bears interest at LIBOR plus 0.85% and matures in February&nbsp;2010. There is an interest rate cap agreement on the new loan that effectively prevents LIBOR from exceeding
6.65%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On July&nbsp;31, 2004, this construction loan matured and was replaced with a three-year loan, plus two one-year extension options at LIBOR
plus 1.65%. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the total interest rate was 6.03%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(10)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Both of these loans were paid off in full on January&nbsp;3, 2006.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(11)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represented a $225.0&nbsp;million construction loan which bore interest at LIBOR plus 2.50%. The loan converted to a fixed rate loan at 7.00% on
August&nbsp;19, 2005, due to the completion and stabilization of the expansion and redevelopment project. NML is the lender for 50% of the construction loan. The funds advanced by NML are considered
related party debt as they are a joint venture partner with the Company in Macerich Northwestern Associates.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(12)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The floating rate loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 1.75%. The total interest rate at December&nbsp;31, 2005 was 6.0%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(13)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This floating rate loan was issued on February&nbsp;18, 2004. The loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 1.375% and matures February&nbsp;20, 2006 with a
one-year extension option. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the total interest rate was 4.75%. The Company has extended the maturity date to March&nbsp;31, 2006. The Company is in the
process of refinancing this loan.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(14)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The property has a construction note payable which shall not exceed $54.0&nbsp;million, which bore interest at LIBOR plus 2.00%. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the
total interest rate was 5.62%. On September&nbsp;22, 2005, this loan was modified to increase the loan to $56.0&nbsp;million, and to reduce the interest rate to LIBOR plus 1.25%. The loan matures
on September&nbsp;16, 2008 and has two one-year extension options.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(15)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The property has a construction note payable which shall not exceed $11.4&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the total
interest rate was 5.64%. On December&nbsp;16, 2005, the joint venture refinanced the existing loan with a $21.4&nbsp;million loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.25%. The loan matures on
December&nbsp;16, 2007 and has one twelve-month extension option.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(16)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On October 4, 2005, the joint venture refinanced the existing loan on the property with a $41.5&nbsp;million loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 0.69%. The loan
matures on October&nbsp;9, 2007, and has three one-year extension options. This floating rate debt is covered by an interest rate cap agreement over the loan term which effectively prevents LIBOR
from exceeding 8.54%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(17)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On March 1, 2006, the joint venture refinanced the existing loan on the property with a $51.5&nbsp;million floating rate loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.10%.
The loan matures in February 2008 and has three one year extension options.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(18)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note was assumed at acquisition. The loan consists of 3 traunches, with a range of maturities from 36&nbsp;months (with two 18-month extension
options) to 60&nbsp;months. The floating rate debt ranges from LIBOR plus 0.60% to LIBOR plus 2.50%, and fixed rate debt ranges from 5.01% to 6.18%. This loan is part of a larger loan group, and is
cross-collateralized and cross-defaulted with the other properties in that group, which are unaffiliated with the Company. An interest rate swap was entered into to convert $0.4&nbsp;million of
floating rate debt with a weighted average interest rate of 3.97% to a fixed rate of 5.39%. The interest rate swap has been designated as a hedge in accordance with Statement on Financial Accounting
Standards ("SFAS") No.133, "Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities." Additionally, interest rate caps were entered into on a portion of the debt and reverse interest rate caps
were simultaneously sold to offset the effect of the interest rate cap agreements. These interest rate caps do not qualify for hedge accounting in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;133.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(19)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On January 11, 2005, concurrent with the acquisition of the property, the joint venture entered into a mortgage loan of $112.0&nbsp;million, which bears interest at
LIBOR plus 0.94%. The loan matures on February&nbsp;9, 2008 and has two one-year extension options. The joint venture entered into an interest rate swap agreement for $112.0&nbsp;million to
convert this loan from floating to fixed at a rate of 3.86%, which effectively limits the interest rate on this loan to 4.80%. The interest rate swap has been designated as a hedge in accordance with
SFAS No.&nbsp;133.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(20)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On January 11, 2005, concurrent with the acquisition of the property, the joint venture entered into a loan for $37.38&nbsp;million, which bears interest at LIBOR
plus 3.45%. The weighted average interest rate at December&nbsp;31, 2005 was 7.82%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(21)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The annual debt service represents the payment of principal and interest. In addition, contingent interest, as defined in the loan agreement, is due upon the
occurrence
of certain capital events and is equal to 15% of proceeds less the base amount.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(22)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In connection with the acquisition of these Centers, the joint venture assumed $485.0&nbsp;million of mortgage notes payable which are collateralized by the
properties. At acquisition, the $300.0&nbsp;million fixed rate portion of this debt reflected a fair value of $322.7&nbsp;million, which included an unamortized premium of $22.7&nbsp;million.
This premium is being amortized as interest expense over the life of the loan using the effective interest method. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the unamortized balance of the debt premium was
$1.3&nbsp;million.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> On April&nbsp;12, 2000, the joint venture issued $138.5&nbsp;million of additional mortgage notes, which are collateralized by the properties and are due in May&nbsp;2006. $57.1&nbsp;million
of this debt requires fixed monthly interest payments of $0.4&nbsp;million at a weighted average rate of 8.13% while the floating rate notes of $81.4&nbsp;million require monthly interest payments
at a floating weighted average rate (based on LIBOR) of 4.74% at December&nbsp;31, 2005. This floating rate debt is covered by an interest rate cap agreement which effectively prevents LIBOR from
exceeding 11.83%.  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<A NAME="page_dg1080_1_34"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> $184.5&nbsp;million of this debt was refinanced in May&nbsp;2003 with a new loan of $186.5&nbsp;million that requires monthly interest payments at a floating weighted average rate (based on
LIBOR) of 4.79% at December&nbsp;31, 2005. This floating rate debt is covered by interest rate cap agreements, which effectively prevent LIBOR from exceeding 10.63%.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Management of the joint venture anticipates it will successfully refinance the existing debt, all of which matures in May 2006, with debt having similar terms to the current debt.  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(23)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I>The property has a construction note payable which shall not exceed $28.0&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. At
December&nbsp;31, 2005, the total interest rate was 6.57%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(24)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note was assumed at acquisition. The loan consists of 3 tranches, with a range of maturities from 36&nbsp;months (with two 18-month extension
options) to 60&nbsp;months. The floating rate debt ranges from LIBOR plus 0.60% to LIBOR plus 2.5%, and fixed rate debt ranges from 5.01% to 6.18%. This loan is part of a larger loan group, and is
cross-collateralized and cross-defaulted with the other properties in that group, which are unaffiliated with the Company. An interest rate swap was entered into that converts $3.0&nbsp;million of
floating rate debt with a weighted average interest rate of 3.97% to a fixed rate of 5.39%. The interest rate swap has been designated as a hedge in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;133. Additionally,
interest rate caps were entered into on a portion of the debt and reverse interest rate caps were simultaneously sold to offset the effect of the interest rate cap agreements. These interest rate caps
do not qualify for hedge accounting in accordance with SFAS No. 133.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(25)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On October 7, 2004, the joint venture placed an additional mortgage loan on the property totaling $35.0&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.00%.
</I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> <A NAME="dg1080_item_3._legal_proceedings"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dg1080_2"> </A>
<BR>    </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 3. Legal Proceedings    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>None of the Company, the Operating Partnership, Macerich Property Management Company, LLC, Macerich Management Company, the Westcor Management Companies, Wilmorite Management
Companies or their respective affiliates are currently involved in any material litigation nor, to the Company's knowledge, is any material litigation currently threatened against such entities or the
Centers, other than routine litigation arising in the ordinary course of business, most of which is expected to be covered by liability insurance. For information about certain environmental matters,
see "Business&#151;Environmental Matters." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dg1080_item_4._submission_of_matters___ite02419"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dg1080_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 4. Submission of Matters to a Vote of Securities Holders    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>None </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=36,EFW="2167716",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1018715,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK128:[06BHL0.06BHL1080]DG1080A.;44',USER='GKIBBE',CD=';9-MAR-2006;13:52' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_di1080_1_35"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="di1080_part_ii"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di1080_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Part II    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="di1080_item_5._market_for_registrant___ite04666"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di1080_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 5. Market for Registrant's Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The common stock of the Company is listed and traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "MAC". The common stock began trading on March&nbsp;10, 1994 at a price of
$19 per share. In 2005, the Company's shares traded at a high of $71.22 and a low of $53.10. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
of February&nbsp;24, 2006, there were approximately 961 stockholders of record. The following table shows high and low closing prices per share of common stock during each quarter in 2004 and
2005 and dividends/distributions per share of common stock declared and paid by quarter: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company issued 3,627,131 shares of its Series&nbsp;A cumulative convertible redeemable preferred stock ("Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock"). There is no established public
trading market for the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock was issued on February&nbsp;25, 1998. Preferred stock dividends are accrued quarterly and paid in arrears.
The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock can be converted on a one for one basis into common stock and will pay a quarterly dividend equal to the greater of $0.46 per share, or the dividend then payable on
a share of common stock. No dividends will be declared or paid on any class of common or other junior stock to the extent that dividends on Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock have not been declared
and/or paid. The </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's existing financing agreements limit, and any other financing agreements that the Company enters into in the future will likely limit, the Company's ability to pay
cash dividends. Specifically, the Company may pay cash dividends and make other distributions based on a formula derived from Funds from Operations (See Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of
Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#151;Funds From Operations) and only if no event of default under the financing agreements has occurred, unless, under certain circumstances,
payment of the distribution is necessary to enable the Company to qualify as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> During 2001, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combination ". (See "Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations&#151;Statement on Critical Accounting Policies") The amortization of above and below market leases, which is recorded in minimum rents, was $11.6&nbsp;million, $9.2&nbsp;million,
$6.1&nbsp;million and $1.1&nbsp;million for the years ending December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Unconsolidated joint ventures include all Centers and entities in which the Company does not have a controlling ownership interest and for Macerich Management
Company through
June&nbsp;30, 2003 and for Macerich Property Management Company through
March&nbsp;28, 2001. Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Macerich Property Management Company merged with and into MPMC, LLC. The Company accounts for the joint ventures using the equity method of
accounting. Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Company began consolidating the accounts for MPMC, LLC. Effective July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company began to consolidate Macerich Management Company, in
accordance with FIN 46. Effective July&nbsp;26, 2002, the Company consolidated the accounts of the Westcor Management Companies.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> "Minority Interest" reflects the ownership interest in the Operating Partnership and other entities not owned by the REIT.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company's Taxable REIT Subsidiaries ("TRSs") are subject to corporate level income taxes (See Note&nbsp;2 of the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements).
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In 2002, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;144, "Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets." (See "Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis
of
Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#151;Statement on Critical Accounting Policies")  </I></FONT>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Boulder Plaza on March&nbsp;19, 2002 and in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;144, the results of Boulder Plaza for the periods from January&nbsp;1, 2002 to March&nbsp;19, 2002
and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000 have been classified as discontinued operations. Total revenues associated with Boulder Plaza were approximately $0.5&nbsp;million for the
period January&nbsp;1, 2002 to March&nbsp;19, 2002 and $2.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Additionally, the Company sold its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway on January&nbsp;2, 2003 (acquired in July&nbsp;2002), and the loss on sale of $0.2&nbsp;million has been classified as
discontinued operations in 2003. Total revenues associated with Paradise Village Gateway for the period ending December&nbsp;31, 2002 were $2.4&nbsp;million. The Company sold Bristol Center on
August&nbsp;4, 2003, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2003 to August&nbsp;4, 2003 and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, and 2001 have been classified as discontinued
operations. The sale of Bristol Center resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $22.2&nbsp;million in  </I></FONT></P>

</DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_di1080_1_39"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> 2003. Total revenues associated with Bristol Center were approximately $2.5&nbsp;million for the period January&nbsp;1, 2003 to August&nbsp;4, 2003 and $4.0&nbsp;million and
$3.3&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, respectively.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company sold Westbar on December&nbsp;16, 2004, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2004 to December&nbsp;16, 2004 and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and for the
period July&nbsp;26, 2002 to December&nbsp;31, 2002 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of Westbar resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $6.8&nbsp;million. Total revenues
associated with Westbar were approximately $4.8&nbsp;million for the period January&nbsp;1, 2004 to December&nbsp;17, 2004 and $5.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and
$2.1&nbsp;million for the period July&nbsp;26, 2002 to December&nbsp;31, 2002.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> On January&nbsp;5, 2005, the Company sold Arizona Lifestyle Galleries. The sale of this property resulted in a gain on sale of $0.3&nbsp;million and the impact on the results of operations for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 were insignificant.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> Additionally, the results of Crossroads Mall in Oklahoma for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and 2001 have been classified as discontinued operations. The Company has
identified this asset for disposition. Total revenues associated with
Crossroads Mall were approximately $10.9&nbsp;million, $11.2&nbsp;million, $12.2&nbsp;million, $11.8&nbsp;million and $12.0&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004,
2003, 2002, and 2001, respectively.  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Assumes that all OP Units and Westcor partnership units are converted to common stock on a one-for-one basis. The Westcor partnership units were converted into
OP Units on July&nbsp;27, 2004, which were subsequently redeemed for common stock on October&nbsp;4, 2005.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Assumes issuance of common stock for in-the-money options and restricted stock calculated using the treasury method in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;128 for
all years presented.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company uses Funds from Operations ("FFO") in addition to net income to report its operating and financial results and considers FFO and FFO-diluted as
supplemental
measures for the real estate industry and a supplement to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ("GAAP") measures. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT") defines FFO
as net income (loss) (computed in accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (or losses) from extraordinary items and sales of depreciated operating properties, plus real estate related depreciation and
amortization and after adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures. Adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures are calculated to reflect FFO on the same basis.
FFO and FFO on a fully diluted basis are useful to investors in comparing operating and financial results between periods. This is especially true since FFO excludes real estate depreciation and
amortization as the Company believes real estate values fluctuate based on market conditions rather than depreciating in value ratably on a straight-line basis over time. FFO on a fully
diluted basis is one of the measures investors find most useful in measuring the dilutive impact of outstanding convertible securities. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations as defined by
GAAP should not be considered as an alternative to net income as defined by GAAP, and is not indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO as presented may not be comparable to
similarly titled measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income, see "Item 7, Management's Discussion and Analysis of
Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#151;Funds from Operations."  </I></FONT>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The computation of FFO-diluted includes the effect of outstanding common stock options and restricted stock using the treasury method. It also assumes the conversion of MACWH, LP units to
the extent that they are dilutive to the FFO computation (See Note&nbsp;15&#151;Wilmorite Acquisition of the Company's Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements). The Company had
$125.1&nbsp;million of convertible subordinated debentures (the "Debentures") which matured December&nbsp;15, 2002. The Debentures were dilutive for the twelve month periods ending
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001 and were included in the FFO calculation. The Debentures were paid off in full on December&nbsp;13, 2002. On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold
$100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. On June&nbsp;16, 1998, the Company sold $150&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. The Preferred Stock can be converted
on a one-for-one basis for common stock. The Series&nbsp;A and Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock then outstanding was dilutive to FFO in 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and 2001 and was
dilutive to net income in 2003. All of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock was converted to common stock on September&nbsp;9, 2003.  </I></FONT></P>

</DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1080_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1080_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>This Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K contains or incorporates statements that constitutes forward-looking statements. Those statements appear in a number of
places in this Form&nbsp;10-K and include statements regarding, among other matters, the Company's growth, acquisition, redevelopment and development opportunities, the Company's
acquisition and other strategies, regulatory matters pertaining to compliance with governmental regulations and other factors affecting the Company's financial condition or results of operations.
Words such as "expects," "anticipates," "intends," "projects," "predicts," "plans," "believes," "seeks," "estimates," and "should" and variations of these words and similar expressions, are used in
many cases to identify these forward-looking statements. Stockholders are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties
and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements of the Company or industry to vary materially from the Company's future results, performance or achievements, or those of
the industry, expressed or implied in such forward-looking statements. Such factors include the matters described herein and under "Item&nbsp;1A. Risk Factors," among others. The Company will not
update any forward-looking information to reflect actual results or changes in the factors affecting the forward-looking information. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1080_management_s_overview_and_summary"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1080_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Management's Overview and Summary    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Macerich Company (the "Company") is involved in the acquisition, ownership, development, redevelopment, management, and leasing of regional and community shopping centers
located throughout the United States. The Company is the sole general partner of, and owns a majority of the ownership interests in, The Macerich Partnership, L.P., a Delaware limited partnership
(the "Operating Partnership"). As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Operating Partnership owned or had an ownership interest in 75 regional shopping centers, 20 community shopping centers and two
development properties aggregating approximately 78.9&nbsp;million square feet of gross leasable area ("GLA"). These 97 regional, community and development shopping centers are referred to
hereinafter as the "Centers", unless the context otherwise requires. The Company is a self-administered and self-managed real estate
investment trust ("REIT") and conducts all of its operations through the Operating Partnership and the Company's management companies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following discussion is based primarily on the consolidated financial statements of the Company for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003. The following discussion compares the
activity for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 to results of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. Also included is a comparison of the activities for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004 to the results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003. This information should be read in conjunction with the accompanying consolidated financial statements and notes
thereto. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions and dispositions  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The financial statements reflect the following acquisitions, dispositions and changes in ownership subsequent to the occurrence of each transaction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;2, 2003, the Company sold its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway, a 296,153 square foot Phoenix area urban village, for approximately $29.4&nbsp;million. The proceeds from
the sale were used to repay a portion of the term loan. The sale resulted in a loss on sale of asset of $0.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=42,EFW="2167716",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=188205,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK128:[06BHL0.06BHL1080]DK1080A.;21',USER='KSOLTER',CD=';7-MAR-2006;23:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1080_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's 50% interest in FlatIron Crossing. The purchase price consisted of approximately $68.3&nbsp;million in cash plus the
assumption of the joint venture partner's share of debt of $90.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company sold 49.9% of its partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera for a total purchase price of approximately $65.9&nbsp;million, which included the
assumption of a proportionate amount of the partnership debt in the amount of approximately $34.7&nbsp;million. The Company retained a 50.1% partnership interest and has continued leasing and
managing the asset. The sale resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $8.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;6, 2003, the Shops at Gainey Village, a 138,000 square foot Phoenix area specialty center, was sold for $55.7&nbsp;million. The Company, which owned 50% of this property, received
total proceeds of $15.8&nbsp;million and recorded a gain on sale of asset of $2.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
August&nbsp;4, 2003, the Company sold Bristol Center, a 161,000 square foot community center in Santa Ana, California. The sales price was approximately $30.0&nbsp;million and the Company
recorded a gain on sale of asset of $22.2&nbsp;million which is reflected in discontinued operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company acquired Northridge Mall, an 864,000 square foot super-regional mall in Salinas, California. The total purchase price was $128.5&nbsp;million and was
funded by sale proceeds from Bristol Center and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. Northridge Mall is referred herein as the "2003 Acquisition Center." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;18, 2003, the Company acquired Biltmore Fashion Park, a 600,000 square foot regional mall in Phoenix, Arizona. The total purchase price was $158.5&nbsp;million, which included
the assumption of $77.4&nbsp;million of debt. The Company also issued 705,636 partnership units of the Operating Partnership at a price of $42.80 per unit. The balance of the Company's 50% share of
the purchase price of $10.5&nbsp;million was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. The mall is owned in a <SUP>50</SUP>/<SMALL>50</SMALL> joint venture with an institutional
partner. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;30, 2004, the Company, in a <SUP>50</SUP>/<SMALL>50</SMALL> joint venture with a private investment company, acquired Inland Center, a 1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in San
Bernardino, California. The total purchase price was $63.3&nbsp;million and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $54.0&nbsp;million fixed rate loan on the property. The
Company's share of the remainder of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;11, 2004, the Company acquired an ownership interest in NorthPark Center, a 1.4&nbsp;million square foot regional mall in Dallas, Texas. The Company's initial investment in the
property was $30.0&nbsp;million which was funded by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. In addition, the Company assumed a pro rata share of debt of $86.6&nbsp;million and funded an
additional $45.0&nbsp;million post-closing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company acquired the Mall of Victor Valley in Victorville, California and on July&nbsp;20, 2004, the Company acquired La Cumbre Plaza in Santa Barbara, California. The
Mall of Victor Valley is a 480,000 square foot regional mall and La Cumbre Plaza is a 495,000 square foot regional mall. The </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

total purchase price was $151.3&nbsp;million. The purchase price for the Mall of Victor Valley included the assumption of an existing fixed rate loan of $54.0&nbsp;million at 5.25%

Paradise Village Office Park II. All of these assets are located in Phoenix, Arizona. The total purchase price was $50.0&nbsp;million which included the assumption of the unaffiliated owners' share

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;5, 2005, the Company sold Arizona Lifestyle Galleries for $4.3&nbsp;million. The sale resulted in a gain on sale on asset of $0.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;11, 2005, the Company became a 15% owner in a joint venture that acquired Metrocenter, a 1.3&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Phoenix, Arizona. The total purchase
price was $160&nbsp;million and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $112&nbsp;million loan on the property. The Company's share of the purchase price, net of the debt,
was $7.2&nbsp;million which was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;21, 2005, the Company formed a <SUP>50</SUP>/<SMALL>50</SMALL> joint venture with a private investment company. The joint venture acquired a 49% interest in Kierland Commons, a 437,000 square
foot mixed use center in Phoenix, Arizona. The joint venture's purchase price for the interest in the center was $49.0&nbsp;million. The Company assumed its share of the underlying property debt
and funded the remainder of its share of the purchase price by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;8, 2005, the Company acquired Ridgmar Mall, a 1.3&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Fort Worth, Texas. The acquisition was completed in a <SUP>50</SUP>/<SMALL>50</SMALL> joint
venture with an affiliate of Walton Street Capital, LLC. The purchase price was $71.1&nbsp;million. Concurrent with the closing, a $57.4&nbsp;million loan bearing interest at a fixed rate of
6.0725% was placed on the property. The balance of the purchase price was funded by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=44,EFW="2167716",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=562259,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK128:[06BHL0.06BHL1080]DK1080A.;21',USER='KSOLTER',CD=';7-MAR-2006;23:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1080_1_43"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;25, 2005, the Company and the Operating Partnership completed its acquisition of Wilmorite Properties,&nbsp;Inc., a Delaware corporation ("Wilmorite") and Wilmorite Holdings, L.P.,
a Delaware limited partnership ("Wilmorite Holdings"). Wilmorite's portfolio includes interests in 11 regional malls and two open-air community shopping centers with 13.4&nbsp;million
square feet of space located in Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Kentucky and Virginia. The total purchase price was approximately $2.333&nbsp;billion, plus adjustments for working capital,
including the assumption of approximately $877.2&nbsp;million of existing debt with an average interest rate of 6.43% and the issuance of $234&nbsp;million of convertible preferred units ("CPUs")
and $5.8&nbsp;million of common units in Wilmorite Holdings. The balance of the consideration to the equity holders of Wilmorite and Wilmorite Holdings was paid in cash, which was provided
primarily by a five-year, $450&nbsp;million term loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.50% and a $650&nbsp;million acquisition loan with a term of up to two years and bearing interest
initially at LIBOR plus 1.60%. An affiliate of the Operating Partnership is the general partner and, together with other affiliates, own approximately 83% of Wilmorite Holdings, with the remaining
17% held by those limited partners of Wilmorite Holdings who elected to receive CPUs or common units in Wilmorite Holdings rather than cash. Approximately $213&nbsp;million of the CPUs can be
redeemed, subject to certain conditions, for the portion of the Wilmorite portfolio generally located in the area of Rochester, New York. The Wilmorite portfolio, exclusive of Tysons Corner Center
and Tysons Corner Office (collectively referred herein as "Tysons Center"), are referred to herein as the "2005 Wilmorite Centers." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Mall of Victor Valley, La Cumbre Plaza, Fiesta Mall, Paradise Village Ground Leases, Village Center, Village Crossroads, Village Fair and Paradise Village Office Park II are referred to herein as
the "2004 Acquisition Centers." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Biltmore
Fashion Park, Inland Center, Kierland Commons, Metrocenter, NorthPark Center, Ridgmar Mall and Tysons Center are joint ventures and these properties are reflected using the equity method of
accounting. The Company's share of the results of these acquisitions are reflected in the consolidated results of operations of the Company in the income statement line item entitled "Equity in
income of unconsolidated joint ventures." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Many
of the variations in the results of operations, discussed below, occurred due to the transactions described above including the acquisition of the 2005 Wilmorite Centers and the 2004 Acquisition
Centers. Kierland Commons, Metrocenter, Ridgmar Mall and Tysons Center are referred to herein as the "2005 Joint Venture Acquisition Centers." Biltmore Fashion Park, Inland Center and NorthPark
Center are referred to herein as the "2004 Joint Venture Acquisition Centers." 29<SUP>th</SUP> Street, Parklane Mall, Santa Monica Place and Queens Center were under redevelopment during all or a
portion of the reporting periods and are referred to herein as the "Redevelopment Centers." La Encantada and Scottsdale 101 were under development during all or a portion of the reporting periods and
are referred to herein as the "Development Properties." All other Centers, excluding the Redevelopment Centers, the Development Properties, the 2005 Wilmorite Centers, the 2004 Acquisition Centers,
the 2005 Joint Venture Acquisition Centers and the 2004 Acquisition Centers, are referred to herein as the "Same Centers," unless the context otherwise requires. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Inflation  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In the last three years, inflation has not had a significant impact on the Company because of a relatively low inflation rate. Most of the leases at the Centers have rent
adjustments periodically through the lease </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=45,EFW="2167716",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=580137,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK128:[06BHL0.06BHL1080]DK1080A.;21',USER='KSOLTER',CD=';7-MAR-2006;23:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1080_1_44"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>term.
These rent increases are either in fixed increments or based on using an annual multiple of increases in the Consumer Price Index ("CPI"). In addition, about 6%-13% of the leases
expire each year, which enables the Company to replace existing leases with new leases at higher base rents if the rents of the existing leases are below the then existing market rate. Additionally,
historically the majority of the leases require the tenants to pay their pro rata share of operating expenses. In January 2005, the Company began entering into leases that require tenants to pay a
stated amount for operating expenses, generally excluding property taxes, regardless of the expenses actually incurred at any center. This change shifts the burden of cost control to the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Seasonality  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The shopping center industry is seasonal in nature, particularly in the fourth quarter during the holiday season when retailer occupancy and retail sales are typically at their
highest levels. In addition, shopping malls achieve a substantial portion of their specialty (temporary retailer) rents during the holiday season and the majority of percentage rent is recognized in
the fourth quarter. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1080_critical_accounting_policies"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1080_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Critical Accounting Policies    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") defines "critical accounting policies" as those that require application of management's most difficult, subjective or complex
judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain and may change in subsequent periods. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect
the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the
reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Some
of these estimates and assumptions include judgments on revenue recognition, estimates for common area maintenance and real estate tax accruals, provisions for uncollectible accounts, impairment
of long-lived assets, the allocation of purchase price between tangible and intangible assets, and estimates for environmental matters. The Company's significant accounting policies are
described in more detail in Note&nbsp;2 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. However, the following policies are deemed to be critical. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenue Recognition  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the terms of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a year and the
amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight lining of rent adjustment." Currently, 37% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions for CPI rent increases periodically
throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that using an annual multiple of CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that more closely
matches the cash revenue from each lease and will provide more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. Percentage rents are recognized when the tenants' specified sales targets have
been met. Estimated recoveries from tenants for real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses are
incurred. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=46,EFW="2167716",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1009321,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK128:[06BHL0.06BHL1080]DK1080A.;21',USER='KSOLTER',CD=';7-MAR-2006;23:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1080_1_45"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Property  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs related to the development, redevelopment, construction and improvement of properties are capitalized. Interest incurred or imputed on development, redevelopment and
construction projects is capitalized until construction is substantially complete. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc. are capitalized and
depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Buildings and improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-40 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>initial term of related lease</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Acquisitions  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company accounts for all acquisitions entered into subsequent to June&nbsp;30, 2001 in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS")
No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combinations." The Company will first determine the value of the land and buildings utilizing an "as if vacant" methodology. The Company will then assign a fair value to any
debt assumed at acquisition. The balance of the purchase price will be allocated to tenant improvements and identifiable intangible assets or liabilities. Tenant improvements represent the tangible
assets associated with the existing leases valued on a fair market value basis at acquisition date prorated over the remaining lease terms. The tenant improvements are classified as an asset under
real estate investments and are depreciated over the remaining lease terms. Identifiable intangible assets and liabilities relate to the value of in-place operating leases which come in
three forms: (i)&nbsp;origination value, which represents the value associated with "cost avoidance" of acquiring in-place leases, such as lease commissions paid under terms generally
experienced in our markets; (ii)&nbsp;value of in-place leases, which represents the estimated loss of revenue and of costs incurred for the period required to lease the "assumed
vacant" property to the occupancy level when purchased; and (iii)&nbsp;above or below market value of in-place leases, which represents the difference between the contractual rents and
market rents at the time of the acquisition, discounted for tenant credit risks. Origination value is recorded as an other asset and is amortized over the remaining lease terms. Value of
in-place leases is recorded as another asset and amortized over the remaining lease term plus an estimate of renewal of the acquired leases. Above or below market leases are classified as
an other asset or liability, depending on whether the contractual terms are above or below market, and the asset or liability is amortized to rental revenue over the remaining terms of the leases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>When
the Company acquires real estate properties, the Company allocates the purchase price to the components of these acquisitions using relative fair values computed using its estimates and
assumptions. These estimates and assumptions impact the amount of costs allocated between various components as well as the amount of costs assigned to individual properties in multiple property
acquisitions. These allocations also impact depreciation expense and gains or loses recorded on future sales of properties. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=47,EFW="2167716",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=801926,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK128:[06BHL0.06BHL1080]DK1080A.;21',USER='KSOLTER',CD=';7-MAR-2006;23:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1080_1_46"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Generally,
the Company engages a valuation firm to assist with the allocation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company assesses whether there has been impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering factors such as expected future operating income, trends
and prospects, as well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenant's ability to perform their duties and pay rent under the terms of the leases.
The Company may recognize impairment losses if the cash flows are not sufficient to cover its investment. Such a loss would be determined as the difference between the carrying value and the fair
value of a center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deferred Charges  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Cost relating to
financing of shopping center properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method.
In-place lease values are amortized over the remaining lease term plus an estimate of renewal. Leasing commissions and legal costs are amortized on a straight-line basis over
the individual remaining lease years. The range of the terms of the agreements are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

</TR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> <A NAME="dk1080_comparison_of_years_ended_december_31,_2005_and_2004"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1080_4"> </A>
<BR>    </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents increased by 40.4% to $487.5&nbsp;million in 2005 from $347.3&nbsp;million in 2004. Approximately $92.9&nbsp;million of the increase relates
to the 2005 Wilmorite Centers, $1.6&nbsp;million relates to the Same Centers, $21.6&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $24.1&nbsp;million primarily relates to Queens
Center and the Development Properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
amount of straight-lined rents, included in minimum rent, was $6.7&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to $1.0&nbsp;million in 2004. This increase in straight-lining of rents relates to the 2005
Wilmorite Centers and the 2004 Acquisition Centers which is offset by decreases resulting from the Company structuring the majority of its new leases using an annual multiple of CPI increases, which
generally do not require straight-lining treatment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
amortization of above and below market leases, which is recorded in minimum rents, increased to $11.6&nbsp;million in 2005 from $9.2&nbsp;million in 2004. The increase is primarily due to the
2005 Wilmorite Centers and the 2004 Acquisition Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $229.5&nbsp;million in 2005 from $159.0&nbsp;million in 2004. Approximately $52.9&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the 2005 Wilmorite Centers,
$5.3&nbsp;million relates to Queens Center </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dk1080_1_47"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>and
the Development Properties, $9.2&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $3.1&nbsp;million relates to the Same Centers. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management
Companies' revenues increased by 21.4% to $26.1&nbsp;million in 2005 from $21.5&nbsp;million in 2004 primarily due to increased management fees received from the 2005 and 2004 Joint
Venture Acquisition Centers and third party management contracts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Shopping Center and Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center and operating expenses increased to $243.8&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to $164.5&nbsp;million in 2004. This increase is a result of $54.9&nbsp;million
of expenses from the 2005 Wilmorite Centers, $10.5&nbsp;million from the 2004 Acquisition Centers, $5.5&nbsp;million from Queens Center and the Development Properties and $2.0&nbsp;million from
increased operating and ground rent expenses at the Same Centers. In addition, there was a write-off of a contingent compensation liability of $6.4&nbsp;million in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Management Companies' Operating Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management Companies' operating expenses increased by 19.7% to $52.8&nbsp;million in 2005 from $44.1&nbsp;million in 2004, primarily due to higher compensation expense in
2005 compared to 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>REIT General and Administrative Expenses  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>REIT general and administrative expenses increased to $12.1&nbsp;million in 2005 from $11.1&nbsp;million in 2004, primarily due to increases in stock-based compensation
expense compared to 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased to $206.1&nbsp;million in 2005 from $142.1&nbsp;million in 2004. Approximately $60.6&nbsp;million relates to the 2005 Wilmorite
Centers, $3.0&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $3.6&nbsp;million relates to Queens Center and the Development Properties. This is offset by a $3.2&nbsp;million decrease
relating to the Same Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased to $249.9&nbsp;million in 2005 from $146.3&nbsp;million in 2004. Approximately $26.6&nbsp;million relates to the assumed debt from the 2005
Wilmorite Centers, $39.8&nbsp;million relates to the term and acquisition loans for the Wilmorite Acquisition, $19.8&nbsp;million relates to increased borrowings and higher interest rates under
the Company's line of credit, $2.0&nbsp;million relates to the Northridge Center loan which closed on June&nbsp;30, 2004, $5.9&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers,
$10.6&nbsp;million relates to Queens Center and the Development Properties and $4.5&nbsp;million relates to an increase in interest rates on floating rate debt at the Same Centers. These
increases are offset in part by a $4.6&nbsp;million decrease related to the payoff of the $250&nbsp;million term loan on July&nbsp;30, 2004. Additionally, capitalized interest was
$10.0&nbsp;million in 2005, down from $8.9&nbsp;million in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest represents the 19.0% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership not owned by the Company during 2005. This compares to 19.5% not owned by the
Company during 2004. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity in Income from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The equity in income from unconsolidated joint ventures was $76.3&nbsp;million for 2005, compared to $54.9&nbsp;million in 2004. This primarily relates to increased net

ventures is the Company's pro rata share of straight-line rents, which increased to $4.8&nbsp;million in 2005 from $1.0&nbsp;million in 2004. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income Tax Benefit  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Income tax benefit from taxable REIT subsidiaries ("TRSs") decreased by $3.4&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to 2004 primarily due to the tax effects of state taxes for states
in which the TRSs are combined with the Company, the tax effect of stock-based compensation and the tax effects related to certain acquired assets in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain on Sale of Assets  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2005, a gain of $1.3&nbsp;million was recorded relating to land sales compared to a $0.9&nbsp;million gain on land sales in 2004. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2005, the Company recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $1.7&nbsp;million related to the refinancing of the Valley View Mall loan. In 2004, the Company
recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $1.6&nbsp;million related to the payoff of a loan at one of the Redevelopment Centers and the payoff of the $250&nbsp;million term loan on
July&nbsp;30, 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The gain on sale of $0.2&nbsp;million in 2005 relates primarily to the sale of Arizona Lifestyle Galleries on January&nbsp;5, 2005. In 2004, the gain on sale primarily
related to the $6.8&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Westbar property on December&nbsp;16, 2004. The decrease in income from discontinued operations relates to the Westbar property. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the factors mentioned above, Funds from Operations ("FFO")&#151;Diluted increased 12.6% to $336.8&nbsp;million in 2005 from
$299.2&nbsp;million in 2004. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income available to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $235.3&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to $213.2&nbsp;million in 2004. The increase is primarily due to the foregoing results at the Centers and
offset by a decrease in distributions of income from unconsolidated joint ventures in 2005 compared to 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities was $131.9&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to $489.8&nbsp;million in 2004. The change resulted primarily from increases in distributions of
capital from unconsolidated joint ventures. This is offset by the joint venture acquisitions of Metrocenter and Kierland Commons, the Company's additional contributions to NorthPark Center and the
decreased development, redevelopment, expansion and </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents increased by 16.3% to $347.3&nbsp;million in 2004 from $298.7&nbsp;million in 2003. Approximately $11.7&nbsp;million of the increase relates
to the Same Centers, $0.8&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the Company acquiring 50% of its joint venture partner's interest in FlatIron Crossing, $7.4&nbsp;million relates to the 2003
Acquisition Center, $10.1&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $22.0&nbsp;million relates to the Redevelopment and Development Centers, primarily Queens Center, La Encantada
and Scottsdale 101 where phases of the developments have been completed. Additionally, these increases in minimum and percentage rents are offset by decreasing revenues of $3.4&nbsp;million related
to the Company's sale of a 49.9% interest in the Village at Corte Madera. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
amortization of above and below market leases, which is recorded in minimum rents, increased to $9.2&nbsp;million in 2004 from $6.1&nbsp;million in 2003. The increase is primarily due to the
2003 Acquisition Center, 2004 Acquisition Centers and the Company acquiring 50% of its joint venture partner's interest in FlatIron Crossing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
amount of straight-lined rents, included in minimum rent, was $1.0&nbsp;million in 2004 as compared to $2.9&nbsp;million in 2003. The decrease is due to the structuring of new leases with
rent increases based upon annual multiples of CPI rather than fixed contractual rent increases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $159.0&nbsp;million in 2004 from $152.7 in 2003. Approximately $0.1&nbsp;million relates to the Company acquiring 50% of its joint venture partner's interest in
FlatIron Crossing, $3.4&nbsp;million relates to the Redevelopment and Development Centers, primarily Queens Center, La Encantada and Scottsdale 101, $4.4&nbsp;million relates to the 2003
Acquisition Center and $3.7&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers. This is offset by a $3.8&nbsp;million decrease due to a change in estimated recovery rates at the Same Centers
and a $1.1&nbsp;million decrease relating to the Company's sale of a 49.9% partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management
Companies' revenues increased by 47.3% to $21.5&nbsp;million in 2004 compared to $14.6&nbsp;million in 2003 primarily due to consolidating Macerich Management Company effective
July&nbsp;1, 2003 in accordance with FIN 46. Prior to July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Macerich Management Company was accounted for using the equity method of accounting. </FONT></P>

$12.9&nbsp;million of depreciation and amortization was recorded for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 compared to the same period in 2003 due to the 2002, 2003 and 2004 acquisitions. This is
offset by a $1.1&nbsp;million decrease relating to the sale of 49.9% of the partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

FlatIron Crossing on November&nbsp;4, 2003, $4.8&nbsp;million relates to the $250&nbsp;million of unsecured notes issued on May&nbsp;13, 2003, $5.3&nbsp;million relates to increased
borrowings on the Company's line of credit, $2.0&nbsp;million relates to the 2003 Acquisition Center, $2.0&nbsp;million relates to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and $8.7&nbsp;million relates
primarily to Queens Center, La Encantada and Scottsdale 101. These increases are offset by $2.0&nbsp;million, which relates to the Company's sale of a 49.9% partnership interest in the Village at
Corte Madera, $4.1&nbsp;million relates to the payoff of the $196.5&nbsp;million term loan on July&nbsp;30, 2004, $2.5&nbsp;million relates to the payoff of the 29<SUP>th</SUP> Street loan
on February&nbsp;3, 2004 and $5.9&nbsp;million relates to other financing activity at the Same Centers. Capitalized interest was $8.9&nbsp;million in 2004, down from $12.1&nbsp;million in
2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest represents the 19.5% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership not owned by the Company during 2004. This compares to 20.74% not owned by the
Company during 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity in Income from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and Macerich Management Company  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The income from unconsolidated joint ventures and the Macerich Management Company was $54.9&nbsp;million for 2004, compared to income of $59.3&nbsp;million in 2003. This
decrease is primarily due to increased depreciation relating to SFAS No.&nbsp;141 on the 2004 Joint Venture Acquisition Centers and consolidating Macerich Management Company effective
July&nbsp;1, 2003 in accordance with FIN 46. Prior to July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Macerich Management Company was accounted for using the equity method of accounting. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income Tax Benefit  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Income tax benefit from TRSs increased by $5.0&nbsp;million in 2004 compared to 2003 primarily due to the tax effects of state taxes for states in which the TRSs are combined
with the Company, the change in tax rates applicable to certain acquired assets, the tax effect of stock-based compensation and the release of a valuation allowance in 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain on Sale of Assets  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2004, a gain of $0.9&nbsp;million was recorded relating to land sales compared to $1.0&nbsp;million of land sales in 2003. A gain of $12.4&nbsp;million in 2003
represents primarily the Company's sale of 49.9% of its partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera on May&nbsp;15, 2003 and the sale of the Shops at Gainey Village. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2004, the Company recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $1.6&nbsp;million related to the payoff of a loan at one of the Redevelopment Centers and the payoff
of the $196.8&nbsp;million term loan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2004, the $7.1&nbsp;million gain on sale relates primarily to the sale of the Westbar property. The gain on sale of $22.0&nbsp;million in 2003 relates primarily to the
sale of Bristol Center on August&nbsp;4, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>51</FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=53,EFW="2167716",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=231851,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK128:[06BHL0.06BHL1080]DM1080A.;28',USER='KSOLTER',CD=';8-MAR-2006;19:38' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1080_1_52"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Income Available to Common Stockholders  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the sale of Bristol Center in 2003, the purchase of the 2003 Acquisition Center and the 2004 Acquisition Centers, the sale of 49.9% of the partnership
interest in the Village at Corte Madera, the Company acquiring 50% of its joint venture partner's interest in FlatIron Crossing, the change in depreciation expense due to SFAS No.&nbsp;141, the
redevelopment of Queens Center, the developments of La Encantada and Scottsdale 101 and the foregoing results, net income available to common stockholders decreased to $82.5&nbsp;million in 2004
from $113.2&nbsp;million in 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $213.2&nbsp;million in 2004 compared to $215.7&nbsp;million in 2003. The decrease is primarily due to the foregoing results at the Centers as
mentioned above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities was $489.8&nbsp;million in 2004 compared to cash used in investing activities of $341.3&nbsp;million in 2003. The change resulted
primarily from the proceeds of $107.2&nbsp;million received in 2003 from the sale of Paradise Village Gateway, the Shops at Gainey Village, Bristol Center and the 49.9% interest in the Village at
Corte Madera which is offset by increased contributions to joint ventures and acquisitions of joint ventures, $291.5&nbsp;million relating to the 2004 Acquisition Centers and by the Company's
purchase of its joint venture partner's 50% interest in FlatIron Crossing on January&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow provided by financing activities was $308.4&nbsp;million in 2004 compared to cash flow provided by financing activities of $115.7&nbsp;million in 2003. The 2004
increase compared to 2003 resulted primarily from $94.1&nbsp;million of additional funding relating to Queens construction loan, the $85.0&nbsp;million Northridge loan, the new
$84.0&nbsp;million loan at Fiesta Mall and increased borrowings under the Company's line of credit, which is offset by the Company acquiring 50% of its joint venture partner's interest in FlatIron
Crossing in January&nbsp;2003, the $32.3&nbsp;million funding of the Panorama loan in the first quarter of 2003 and increased dividends being paid in 2004 compared to 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the factors mentioned above, Funds from Operations&#151;Diluted increased 11.1% to $299.2&nbsp;million in 2004 from $269.1&nbsp;million in
2003. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income available to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company intends to meet its short term liquidity requirements through cash generated from operations, working capital reserves, property secured borrowings, unsecured
corporate borrowings and borrowings under the revolving line of credit. The Company anticipates that revenues will continue to provide necessary funds for its operating expenses and debt service
requirements, and to pay dividends to stockholders in accordance with REIT requirements. The Company anticipates that cash generated from operations, together with cash on hand, will be adequate to
fund capital expenditures which will not be </FONT></P>
